key_points: Kyle Rittenhouse was acquitted on charges related to shooting three white men during civil unrest in Kenosha, Wisconsin, in 2020.
Some pundits suggested that Rittenhouse's acquittal was solely due to his race, speculating a person of color in his position would not be acquitted.
The op-ed argues that self-defense is a legitimate legal defense that has been successfully used by defendants of all races.
Examples of non-white defendants acquitted on self-defense grounds include Tony Bristol, Stephen Spencer, and Jaron Moore among others.
These cases showcase that juries can and do recognize self-defense claims from people of color.
The article also notes instances where charges were dropped against defendants of color when self-defense claims could not be disproven by the state.
The assertion that only white Americans can successfully claim self-defense is refuted with numerous examples.
Kyle Rittenhouse faced significant legal and personal challenges before his acquittal, contradicting the narrative that he effortlessly 'got away with murder'.
The piece highlights examples of white defendants whose self-defense claims were unsuccessful, such as Anthony James Trifiletti.
The opinion piece argues against the notion that Rittenhouse's case sets a racial double standard for self-defense claims.
